title: Psalms Chapter 109 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 109 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 109 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 109.

questions.question: According to Psalms 109:1, to whom is the Psalm of David addressed?
questions.correctAnswer: The chief Musician
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:1 states, 'To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David,' indicating it is addressed to the chief Musician.

questions.question: What do the wicked use against the psalmist according to Psalms 109:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Lying tongue
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:2 says the mouths of the wicked and deceitful are opened against him with a lying tongue.

questions.question: What have the psalmist's adversaries done despite his love, according to Psalms 109:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Rewarded him with evil
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:5 states they have rewarded him evil for good and hatred for his love.

questions.question: Who does the psalmist ask to be set over his adversary in Psalms 109:6?
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked man
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:6 requests, 'Set thou a wicked man over him: and let Satan stand at his right hand.'

questions.question: What fate does the psalmist wish upon the children of his adversary in Psalms 109:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Fatherless and widowed
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:9 says, 'Let his children be fatherless, and his wife a widow.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 109:12, what does the psalmist ask regarding mercy towards his adversary?
options: Let there be none to extend mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Let there be none to extend mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:12 requests that no one extend mercy to his adversary or favor to his fatherless children.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109:16 describe the adversary’s treatment of the poor and needy?
questions.correctAnswer: He persecuted them
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:16 states that the adversary persecuted the poor and needy man.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s condition described in Psalms 109:22?
options: Poor and needy with a wounded heart
questions.correctAnswer: Poor and needy with a wounded heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:22 says, 'For I am poor and needy, and my heart is wounded within me.'

questions.question: What physical effect does fasting have on the psalmist according to Psalms 109:24?
questions.correctAnswer: Weak knees and failing flesh
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:24 states, 'My knees are weak through fasting; and my flesh faileth of fatness.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do in Psalms 109:26?
options: Help and save him according to mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Help and save him according to mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:26 says, 'Help me, O LORD my God: O save me according to thy mercy.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 109:7, the psalmist asks that his adversary’s prayer become sin.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:7 states, 'When he shall be judged, let him be condemned: and let his prayer become sin.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 109:31 declares that the Lord will stand at the right hand of the poor to save him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:31 says, 'For he shall stand at the right hand of the poor, to save him from those that condemn his soul.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 109:28, the psalmist requests that his enemies be blessed while he is cursed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:28 says, 'Let them curse, but bless thou,' meaning the psalmist asks God to bless him, not his enemies.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 109:4: 'For my love they are my _______, but I give myself unto prayer.'
questions.correctAnswer: adversaries
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:4 states, 'For my love they are my adversaries: but I give myself unto prayer.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 109:30: 'I will greatly praise the LORD with my _______, yea, I will praise him among the multitude.'
questions.correctAnswer: mouth
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:30 says, 'I will greatly praise the LORD with my mouth; yea, I will praise him among the multitude.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 109 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 109 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 109, what biblical truth would you share about prayer and trusting God in adversity?
options: Prayer is a vital response even when facing wrongful attacks.
We should ignore enemies and avoid prayer.
God will always remove our enemies immediately.
We should seek revenge instead of praying.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is a vital response even when facing wrongful attacks.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:4 shows David giving himself unto prayer despite adversaries; Psalms 109:21 encourages God to deliver because of His mercy; Psalms 109:26 asks for help according to God's mercy.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109 teach about humility and recognizing personal need before God?
options: Acknowledging poverty and a wounded heart leads to seeking God's mercy.
Pride is necessary to overcome adversaries.
One should hide weaknesses and appear strong.
Self-reliance is better than depending on God.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging poverty and a wounded heart leads to seeking God's mercy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:22 states the psalmist is poor and needy with a wounded heart, which prompts prayer; Psalms 109:26 appeals for God's help and salvation; Psalms 109:21 emphasizes God's mercy as the basis for deliverance.

questions.question: What biblical principle about facing slander and deceit can be learned from Psalms 109?
options: The wicked use lying tongues and hatred without cause against the righteous.
Ignoring deceit is the best way to respond.
One should repay evil with evil.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked use lying tongues and hatred without cause against the righteous.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:2-3 describe wicked and deceitful mouths opened against the psalmist with lying tongues and hatred without cause, illustrating spiritual attacks believers face.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109 instruct us regarding the attitude toward enemies and adversaries?
options: Entrusting judgment and vengeance to God rather than personal retaliation.
Taking revenge quickly to protect oneself.
Ignoring the wrongs done by enemies completely.
questions.correctAnswer: Entrusting judgment and vengeance to God rather than personal retaliation.
questions.explanation: The psalm asks God to judge and condemn the wicked (Psalms 109:7) and to reward adversaries from the LORD (Psalms 109:20), showing reliance on God’s justice.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement due to enemies' attacks. How does Psalms 109 teach about perseverance in faith during trials?
options: Persist in prayer and praise despite hardships.
Give up because enemies are too strong.
questions.correctAnswer: Persist in prayer and praise despite hardships.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:1 shows David not holding peace but praising God; Psalms 109:30 commits to greatly praising the LORD; Psalms 109:26-27 ask for help and acknowledge God's hand.

questions.question: What does Psalms 109 teach about God’s care for the poor and oppressed?
options: God stands at the right hand of the poor to save them.
The poor are to fend for themselves without God's help.
God only helps the rich and powerful.
We should ignore the poor and needy.
questions.correctAnswer: God stands at the right hand of the poor to save them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:31 clearly states God stands at the right hand of the poor to save him from condemnation, demonstrating God’s care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109 address the consequences of a person who persecutes the poor and needy?
options: Such a person will receive curses and judgment.
They will be rewarded for their actions.
Their actions will be overlooked by God.
They will be promoted by the community.
questions.correctAnswer: Such a person will receive curses and judgment.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:16-18 describes how the one who persecuted the poor loved cursing and will have it come upon him, clothed like a garment, indicating divine judgment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 109, it is appropriate to ask God to blot out the memory of the wicked from the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:15 explicitly asks that the memory of the wicked be cut off from the earth, demonstrating the psalmist’s plea for God's justice.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 109 encourages us to repay evil with hatred as a way to uphold justice.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Instead of personal retaliation, Psalms 109:20 calls for the LORD to reward the adversaries, showing that justice belongs to God, not personal revenge.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 109 teaches that during trials a believer's prayer should be grounded in God's ______ because it is good.
questions.correctAnswer: mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:21 asks God to act for His name’s sake because His mercy is good, indicating mercy as the foundation of prayer.

questions.question: When facing false accusations, what attitude does Psalms 109 suggest a believer maintain?
options: Continue loving and praying despite adversaries.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue loving and praying despite adversaries.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:4 states 'For my love they are my adversaries: but I give myself unto prayer,' showing love and prayer as responses.

questions.question: What practical Christian virtue related to family life is highlighted by Psalms 109 in the context of a wicked man’s consequences?
options: God’s judgment may affect the family of a wicked person, underscoring the importance of righteous living.
Family is always spared regardless of individual sin.
Family members should separate from wicked relatives quickly.
God does not judge families for individual sins.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment may affect the family of a wicked person, underscoring the importance of righteous living.
questions.explanation: Verses 109:9-13 describe consequences on children and posterity of the wicked, emphasizing the lasting impact of sin on family and the call for personal righteousness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109 encourage believers to respond in worship despite trials?
options: By praising the LORD greatly among the multitude.
By ceasing worship until troubles pass.
By focusing on personal strength instead of God.
questions.correctAnswer: By praising the LORD greatly among the multitude.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:30 declares the psalmist will greatly praise the LORD with his mouth and among the multitude, showing worship even in adversity.

questions.question: What does Psalms 109 reveal about fasting and physical weakness in spiritual discipline?
options: Fasting may cause physical weakness but strengthens spiritual dependence on God.
Fasting is unnecessary and weakens the believer.
Physical strength is more important than spiritual discipline.
One should avoid fasting to maintain energy.
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting may cause physical weakness but strengthens spiritual dependence on God.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:24 mentions weak knees through fasting and flesh failing, indicating physical hardship accompanying spiritual discipline.

questions.question: According to Psalms 109, what is the appropriate response when enemies curse the believer?
options: Bless the believer and let the enemies be ashamed.
Ignore the situation and say nothing.
Join in cursing to fit in.
questions.correctAnswer: Bless the believer and let the enemies be ashamed.
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:28 says 'Let them curse, but bless thou...; but let thy servant rejoice,' teaching blessing in response to curses.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 109 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 109.

questions.question: In Psalms 109:6, whom does the psalmist ask God to set over his adversary, and what is the significance of this figure in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A wicked man and Satan at his right hand
An angel of light and a cherubim
A righteous judge and the Spirit of the Lord
A foreign king and his army
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked man and Satan at his right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:6 requests God to set a wicked man over the adversary and place Satan at his right hand, indicating the invocation of divine judgment and the presence of an adversarial spiritual force, reflecting ancient Near Eastern beliefs about cosmic conflict.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 109:7-15 where the psalmist pronounces a series of curses against his enemy?
questions.correctAnswer: Imprecatory parallelism
questions.explanation: The psalmist uses imprecatory parallelism in verses 7-15, a poetic device where curses and judgments are layered in parallel structure to emphasize the depth of the plea for divine justice.

questions.question: In Psalms 109:14, the psalmist asks God to remember the iniquity of whose fathers, and why is this significant in the cultural context?
options: The enemy's fathers, emphasizing generational sin
The psalmist's own fathers, signifying repentance
The kings of Israel, invoking royal judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy's fathers, emphasizing generational sin
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:14 calls for remembrance of the enemy's fathers’ iniquities, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern concept of collective family responsibility and generational consequences for sin.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 109:21-31 reflects a turning point from curses to a plea for divine intervention and praise?
options: Petition for mercy and eventual praise
questions.correctAnswer: Petition for mercy and eventual praise
questions.explanation: Verses 21-31 shift from curses to a heartfelt plea for God's mercy and conclude with a vow to praise the LORD, illustrating a literary and theological pivot from judgment to hope.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'let Satan stand at his right hand' in Psalms 109:6 connect to New Testament imagery?
options: It parallels the adversarial role of Satan in Job and the temptation of Jesus
It is a direct reference to Satan being cast down in Revelation
It symbolizes the Holy Spirit’s presence beside believers
It indicates the Messiah’s position at God’s right hand
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the adversarial role of Satan in Job and the temptation of Jesus
questions.explanation: The phrase echoes the adversarial figure in Job and the New Testament's portrayal of Satan as tempter and accuser, highlighting a consistent biblical motif of Satan opposing God's people.

questions.question: What Hebrew word translated as 'wicked' in Psalms 109:6 carries a connotation of moral and ritual impurity, and how does this enrich the psalmist’s curse?
questions.correctAnswer: רָשָׁע (rasha)
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word רָשָׁע (rasha) used for 'wicked' in Psalms 109:6 implies not only moral corruption but also ritual defilement, intensifying the psalmist’s condemnation.

questions.question: In Psalms 109:18, the curse is described as clothing the adversary 'like as with his garment.' What literary device is this, and what is its theological implication?
options: Simile, illustrating the inescapable nature of the curse
questions.correctAnswer: Simile, illustrating the inescapable nature of the curse
questions.explanation: The simile compares the curse to clothing, symbolizing how the adversary is enveloped and cannot remove the consequences of wickedness, highlighting divine justice.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 109 portrays the psalmist as a passive victim who does not engage in prayer or petition to God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist actively prays and petitions God throughout Psalms 109 (e.g., verses 4 and 21), demonstrating engagement rather than passivity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 109:22-24, what physical and emotional conditions does the psalmist describe as a result of his suffering?
options: Poverty, inner wounding, weakness, and reproach
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty, inner wounding, weakness, and reproach
questions.explanation: Verses 22-24 describe the psalmist’s poverty, wounded heart, weak knees from fasting, and being a reproach to others, illustrating deep suffering.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I am gone like the shadow when it declineth' in Psalms 109:23 from a Hebrew poetic perspective?
options: It uses imagery of fading light to symbolize the psalmist’s fading life and influence
It is a literal description of sunset
It refers to the shadow of a temple pillar
It symbolizes the rising of a new king
questions.correctAnswer: It uses imagery of fading light to symbolize the psalmist’s fading life and influence
questions.explanation: This poetic image employs natural phenomena to express the psalmist’s diminishing strength and presence, common in Hebrew lament poetry.

questions.question: In Psalms 109:31, how is God’s role described in relation to the poor, and what New Testament theme does this anticipate?
options: God stands at the right hand of the poor to save them, anticipating Christ’s advocacy for the marginalized
God judges the poor, emphasizing divine wrath
God ignores the poor, reflecting human suffering
God commands the poor to defend themselves
questions.correctAnswer: God stands at the right hand of the poor to save them, anticipating Christ’s advocacy for the marginalized
questions.explanation: The verse portrays God as defender of the poor, a motif fulfilled in the New Testament by Jesus’ ministry to the marginalized.

questions.question: Which cultural practice is reflected in Psalms 109:9-10 where the psalmist prays that the enemy's children be fatherless and wander as beggars?
options: The concept of familial curse and social ostracism
questions.correctAnswer: The concept of familial curse and social ostracism
questions.explanation: The curse extends to the enemy's offspring, reflecting ancient Near Eastern notions of collective punishment and social disgrace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Psalms 109:17, the psalmist says, 'As he loved _______, so let it come unto him.'
questions.correctAnswer: cursing
questions.explanation: Psalms 109:17 states 'As he loved cursing, so let it come unto him,' emphasizing the principle of retributive justice.

questions.question: What is the authorial intent behind the extensive imprecations in Psalms 109, considering the historical context of David as the psalmist?
options: To express deep anguish and seek divine justice against false enemies
To promote violence and war against nations
To establish a new legal code
questions.correctAnswer: To express deep anguish and seek divine justice against false enemies
questions.explanation: The psalm reflects David’s experience of betrayal and injustice, using imprecations to call upon God’s righteous judgment in a time when earthly justice was lacking.

questions.question: How does Psalms 109 relate to the theme of Messiah’s suffering and intercession found in Isaiah and the New Testament?
options: The psalm’s portrayal of innocent suffering and prayer prefigures the Messiah’s role as intercessor
It predicts a political uprising against Rome
It focuses solely on personal revenge with no messianic link
It is a historical record of Israel’s exile
questions.correctAnswer: The psalm’s portrayal of innocent suffering and prayer prefigures the Messiah’s role as intercessor
questions.explanation: Psalms 109’s depiction of undeserved suffering and intercessory prayer anticipates the Messiah’s passion and advocacy described in Isaiah and the New Testament.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 109 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 109 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary request made to God at the beginning of Psalm 109?
options: Hold not thy peace, O God of my praise
questions.correctAnswer: Hold not thy peace, O God of my praise
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:1 opens with the plea for God not to remain silent, emphasizing the urgency of divine intervention. This theme of God hearing and acting on behalf of the righteous is echoed in Psalms 34:17, 86:7, Isaiah 59:1, and Luke 18:7.

questions.question: According to Psalm 109, how do the wicked speak against the psalmist?
questions.correctAnswer: With a lying tongue
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:2 describes the wicked and deceitful opening their mouths against the psalmist with lies. This highlights human sinfulness and false accusation, themes also found in Proverbs 6:16-19, John 8:44, Romans 3:13, and Revelation 12:10.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about his own response to his adversaries in Psalm 109?
questions.correctAnswer: He gives himself unto prayer
questions.explanation: In Psalm 109:4, despite being opposed by those he loves, the psalmist commits himself to prayer. This reflects the biblical doctrine of prayer as a refuge in suffering, consistent with 1 Thessalonians 5:17, Philippians 4:6, Jeremiah 29:12, and Hebrews 4:16.

questions.question: What role is assigned to the wicked man over the psalmist in Psalm 109?
options: Set thou a wicked man over him
questions.correctAnswer: Set thou a wicked man over him
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:6 calls for a wicked man to be set over the adversary, symbolizing divine judgment and the consequences of sin. This theme of God sovereignly permitting judgment is reflected in Exodus 9:16, Romans 9:17, Isaiah 10:5, and John 19:11.

questions.question: What is the fate requested for the wicked man’s children in Psalm 109?
options: Let his children inherit the land
questions.correctAnswer: Let his children be fatherless
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:9 petitions for the wicked man's children to be orphaned, illustrating the severe consequences of sin affecting descendants, a concept seen in Exodus 20:5, Jeremiah 32:18, Ezekiel 18:20, and Matthew 5:45.

questions.question: What is said about mercy toward the wicked man in Psalm 109?
options: Let there be none to extend mercy unto him
questions.correctAnswer: Let there be none to extend mercy unto him
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:12 requests that no mercy be extended to the wicked man, emphasizing justice and the severity of unrepentant sin. This contrasts with God's mercy toward the repentant, as seen in Micah 7:18, Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4, and James 2:13.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s description of the wicked man’s delight and its consequences in Psalm 109?
options: As he loved cursing, so let it come unto him
As he loved blessing, so let it come unto him
As he loved justice, so let it come unto him
As he loved peace, so let it come unto him
questions.correctAnswer: As he loved cursing, so let it come unto him
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:17 pronounces that the wicked man receives according to what he loved—cursing rather than blessing. This principle of reaping according to one’s deeds is biblically consistent with Galatians 6:7, Proverbs 11:31, Jeremiah 17:10, and 2 Corinthians 9:6.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do because of His name and mercy in Psalm 109?
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver me
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:21 requests deliverance from God for His name's sake because His mercy is good. Deliverance as an expression of God's mercy and faithfulness is a major biblical theme shown in Exodus 34:6, Psalm 86:5, Jonah 4:2, and 2 Timothy 2:13.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his own condition in Psalm 109?
options: Poor and needy, and my heart is wounded within me
questions.correctAnswer: Poor and needy, and my heart is wounded within me
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:22 reveals the psalmist’s broken condition, highlighting human frailty and dependence on God’s mercy, similar to themes in Isaiah 66:2, Matthew 5:3, Luke 4:18, and James 5:11.

questions.question: What metaphor does the psalmist use to describe his instability in Psalm 109?
options: I am tossed up and down as the locust
I am like a mighty oak
questions.correctAnswer: I am tossed up and down as the locust
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:23 uses the imagery of being tossed like a locust to express instability and vulnerability. This reflects human frailty and God’s sustaining power, as in Job 7:6, Isaiah 40:6-8, Matthew 10:29-31, and Hebrews 12:1.

questions.question: What physical effects of fasting does the psalmist mention in Psalm 109?
options: My knees are weak; my flesh faileth of fatness
questions.correctAnswer: My knees are weak; my flesh faileth of fatness
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:24 depicts the physical weakness caused by fasting. This shows the cost of spiritual disciplines and suffering, and is comparable to Daniel 10:8, Isaiah 58:5-7, Matthew 6:16-18, and Acts 13:2-3.

questions.question: How do the psalmist’s enemies react to him, according to Psalm 109?
questions.correctAnswer: They shake their heads
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:25 states the enemies reproach the psalmist by shaking their heads. This symbolizes contempt and rejection, resembling the treatment of the righteous in Matthew 27:29, John 9:24, Luke 23:11, and 1 Peter 4:14.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to show through his deliverance in Psalm 109?
options: That this is thy hand; that thou, LORD, hast done it
That I am strong and mighty
That I am wealthy and honored
questions.correctAnswer: That this is thy hand; that thou, LORD, hast done it
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:27 expresses a desire for God's deliverance to be recognized as His work, affirming divine sovereignty and glory. This is consistent with Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 63:12, John 11:40, and Romans 11:36.

questions.question: What contrasting responses does the psalmist desire for himself and his enemies in Psalm 109?
options: Let them curse, but bless thou
Let them bless, but curse thou
questions.correctAnswer: Let them curse, but bless thou
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:28 requests that while enemies curse, God would bless the psalmist, revealing a plea for divine justice and vindication. This contrast appears in Genesis 12:3, Romans 12:14, Matthew 5:44, and 1 Peter 3:9.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s declared attitude toward praising God in Psalm 109?
options: I will greatly praise the LORD with my mouth
I will praise only in private
questions.correctAnswer: I will greatly praise the LORD with my mouth
questions.explanation: Psalm 109:30 affirms the psalmist’s commitment to public praise, demonstrating trust and worship amid adversity. This aligns with Psalms 34:1, Hebrews 13:15, Psalm 150:6, and Revelation 19:5.
